On 24.06.2007, at 15:41, Walden Mathews wrote:

>
> And I think what you and others on this list are still missing is  
> that there
> is
> no "non-idempotent" constraint anywhere.  It would be lunacy.


Why not see it this way (and propably that is what you are saying,  
not sure):

Communication between independent processes is essentially concerned  
with
the coordination of these processes. From this POV, every single  
request is a
single distinct act of coordination and therefore of distinct  
significance.

That is the default - if it was not, the comunication would be  
useless, it would
never achieve any form of coordination.

In addition, some particular kinds of requests are explicitly marked  
as beeing
idempotent. Any request kind that is not marked as idempotent must  
inherently
be non-idempotent - from the point of view of achieving coordination
between processes.


Turn this around to: "If you want to place the same order twice, PUT  
just won't do it".

Jan
